data.title: BeOS versus QNX RTOS
data.meta_description: The BeOS has been an item of interest at Ars for a long time. We're also known to dabble in other alternative OSes as well. Today, we're taking a look at...
data.text:
Mar 6, 2001 Add bookmark #2 but it needs more detail.

I tried QNX RTOS out last week. It was on my old 440BX/P3 450 system that runs BeOS all day, every day, with a small 2 gig Win98 partition.

Whereas everything instantly worked with BeOS when I booted it the first time (ethernet/sound/SCSI Plex CD writer) none of this worked with QNX.

I would have liked to have seen a comparison of Voyager, or even some details about Voyager. Also, is QNX multi-threaded like BeOS?

Anyway, unfortunately, I was unable to test Voyager. I wanted to see how it compared to Net+ on BeOS (I'm sure it is better) but the darned thing kept asking me for a dial up connection even though I'm on a lan with a DHCP server.

It seemed snappy, fast, stable and pretty (worked well with the Voodoo 3),but I couldn't get online, so I booted back into Win98, uninstalled, and then went back to BeOS, the original. Plus it is too much LIKE linux. At least Be is friendly in its directory structure. All that /dev /usr /bin stuff in QNX and Linux just confuses me. It's somewhat better hidden in BeOS.

BeOS- putting the soul back in x86 (if it's not dead yet!?! View image: /infopop/emoticons/icon_eek.gif ) Upvote 0 (0 / 0) Mar 6, 2001 Add bookmark #3 I tried (off and on) this last week to get BeOS up and going with my GeForce and PPPoE DSL. It was horrible. But IIRC, QNX RTP wont run off a NTFS drive, so I just gave up all together.

However, after this article, I reinstalled BeOS, downloaded an older NVIDIA driver and behold! I was in! Then I fiddled for 30 minutes getting PPPoE to work (a hassle with 2 NICs), but here I am in Net Positive, posting away.

Nice article. Motivated me to give it another shot...

CP Upvote 0 (0 / 0) Mar 6, 2001 Add bookmark #10 Thanks for the feedback so far.

Sonoma76: I didn't compare the quality of the browsers as I was reviewing the quality of the OS, not any apps that came with it. Since you asked, I don't mind answering, though. Voyager is certainly a more capable browser than Net+. It's very snappy, and is up to the HTML 3.2 specs. It also does most JavaScript 1.1 (it has three unimplemented methods). Also built in is Flash and RealPlayer. To get those options for Be, you have to buy a third-party product and BeOS Pro, respectively. QNX is also a multithreaded OS.

Nimdok: I'm pretty sure there's going to be a Matrox OpenGL driver. It was only that higher priority had been given to others and it was really flaky. I expect that whenever they release the new stack, a Matrox driver will come with it. They've had good driver support in the past, and I expect they will in the future.

Downix: Hmm...I'd thought that this was a final release. Patch A brought it to ver. 6. If you could give a link to some info about this, that'd be appreciated.

The other thing you can try is an app called EasyMove. It's an input_server add-on that lets you alt-click anywhere on a window to move it.

The easy way to move around windows without mucking with anything is to just move them by dragging the border. Be, like MacOS, doesn't let you resize the window on any part of it. Cheers to a brite and long future for BeOS!â„¢ View image: /infopop/emoticons/icon_cool.gif Ë‡ Upvote 0 (0 / 0) Mar 6, 2001 Add bookmark #28 From an end user standpoint, BeOS would definitely offer a better experience. It's designed to be user friendly, and succeeds quite well.

QNX, otoh, was never designed to run on desktops. It's intended for embedded systems where interfaces don't matter much. It does very well at what it's supposed to do, serve as a reliable, stable rtos.

I don't get why QNX is trying to become an alternative desktop operating system. It has virtually no applications that could be of any use to an end user, and most people have no reason to use a RTOS. Why bother with QNX on the desktop when it has nothing to offer that other *nixes don't? I have QNX and find it quite nice, but it doesn't belong on desktops.

Both operating systems do very well at what they're targetted towards, but BeOS and QNX have completely different target audiences. The project might be transferred to someone else, but I don't think anyone took up the offer. Upvote 0 (0 / 0) Mar 6, 2001 Add bookmark #37 Sorry in advance for the long post.

BeOS is a terrific operating system and would be hard to top, IMHO, if Be, Inc. was still promoting it. The sad fact, however, is that Be no longer considers BeOS a revenue source (go back and read the focus switch announcements again if you're not sure about that), and is acting accordingly. Look how many developers, large and small, have dropped projects because of Be's lack of concern for the desktop. The sad fact is that BeOS is just gliding along with the only momentum supplied by its connection to BeIA. Even BeIA features may or may not be reworked into BeOS if they are developed in coordination with a hardware partner.

So from my view, while Be hasn't explicitly killed BeOS, it has turned down the IV to a very slow drip. In contrast, QSSL is expanding its focus from embedded systems to desktop platforms. RTP's similarities to Linux are intentional; things like full Posix compliance ease the transition of developers and applications. Like Be, QSSL wants self-hosted development environment for embedded systems, IAs, etc. The difference is one of direction. Be moved away from the desktop to devote *full* attention to BeIA. Recall that the promised enhancements to BeOS, like BONE, were underway well *before* the focus switch, not something begun since then. QSSL expanded (not moved -- focus enlargement, not switch) from embedded systems *toward* the desktop.

Having said that, QSSL isn't necessarily "pushing" the desktop market. That opportunity is basically for third-party developers. But here again the contrast to Be is striking. Sure, the occassional Be engineer contributes to BeOS forums, but top QSSL staff are actually active members of the Phoenix Platform Consortium, which is the group working to help make RTP (among other alt OSs) a place on the desktop. And QSSL is very responsive. They *want* feedback and input. This is the exact opposite of the situation with Be, and this alone is very telling regarding the future of these two operating systems.

BeOS is great technology. I've run it and enjoyed it since the DR releases; but Be basically let it go, turning promotion and sales over to a few small outside companies and advocacy over to the remaining fans. This isn't the way to build a market presence. It's amazing how hard Be users hold on despite the Be snub -- another testimony to the technology itself.

But RTP has the potential to be everything BeOS is; remember it's at an early beta stage. The hooks are there for what's needed, but the solutions still have to be implemented in many cases. So people making comparisons should be aware of the current status of both BeOS and QNX RTP.

-- gary_c Upvote 0 (0 / 0) Mar 6, 2001 Add bookmark #38 I think overall it was a very nice introductory article, so thank you, but I thought I'd mention a few other things. I'm a longtime BeOS user, and I tried out QNX's RTP for a little while; it's a nice system, but not as advanced. These certainly aren't the only important omissions, but a few of the more apparent ones:

1. BeOS has far superior filetyping to any other OS out there. It uses MIME typing instead of file extensions (although you can use those, too, if you like). This isn't just a theoretically cool feature; it's very useful. You can easily say "all picture files should open in this particular image viewer except JPGs, which should open in this application. Oh, and this particular image should open in the photo editor" and other things of that nature. Furthermore, if you right-click on a file, you'll get an "Open With..." submenu. This is extremely useful if you want, say, HTML files to open in your browser in general when double-clicked on, but right now you wish to edit the HTML file in your HTML editor. Of course, the "Open With..." menu is dynamically generated live, so no configuration is needed. Be's filetyping system is truly beautiful; QNX doesn't offer anything like it.

2. BFS provides very nice attribute abilities. For example, I have "Artist", "Title", "Playing Time", etc. attributes for all my MP3s, which can then easily be sorted and queried in the system's file manager (Tracker). E-mail messages have "From", "Subject", "Date", etc. attributes and can likewise be sorted and searched upon. Furthermore, it is very easy for users to add their own attributes; "Comments", "To Do", or anything else you can think of. I want to play all songs made in 1989? Easy. I want to find all e-mail messages sent by my brother? Again, easy. QNX offers nothing comparable, nor does any other system.

3. Regarding hardware support, I think I'd have to disagree with the article's conclusion. When I tried RTP (please correct me if this has changed since), it didn't support my USB mouse. Be, however, does and natively supports mouse wheels (for most mice; most USB mouse wheels don't work yet). Furthermore, the BeOS supports a variety of gamepads, joysticks, cameras, and TV cards built-in, and when you factor in third-party drivers, add in scanners, even more gamepads, more video/sound cards, printers, etc; even DVD video is now available (albeit still rough). It's also worth mentioning that the BeOS currently supports hardware-accelerated OpenGL for Voodoo cards; it's just not nearly as fast or complete as the new OpenGL stack will hopefully be. Figuring all this in, I don't see how QNX's support could possibly be seen as better.

Regardless of these oversights, thank you for an excellent introductory article! I would love to see a 10-page or so article detailing many other things (font system, multi-lingual support, media capabilities, etc. etc.) if you ever have the time.
